subject: Re: Simplified exception handling in tests
msgSnippet: ... for test cases where the proper behaviour of the method under test is to throw a particular exception?  Your example shows a return in the catch block so
messageBody:
> When you say to "only catch exceptions that I expect" do you mean
for test cases where the proper behaviour of the method under test is
to throw a particular exception? Your example shows a "return" in the
catch block so I would think that is a "test passed" result.

You're absolutely right. "an expected exception" means "if I catch
this exception, it's fine" -> return because the test passed.

There's a mistake I sometimes see in some tests:

void testXYZ() {
try {
/* ... */
} catch (MyException e) {
return;
}
}

Do not forget to fail the test if you did not catch MyException.
Adding a fail() at the last line (or just before the catch statements)
would do it.

> I'll look at the AssertionFailedError with great interest -- the
lack of an accurate stacktrace is so frustrating!

It's also useful when you write your own assertion methods and you
don't want the method to throw any exception (like the standard JUnit
assert methods).

-Vladimir
